newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: China's Dalian refinery operating at 80-percent.
newsitem.headline: China's Dalian refinery operating at 80-percent.

text.p: China's first SINO-foreign oil refinery venture was currently running at an 80-percent operating rate and was not expected to export any products this year, sources at the refinery said on Thursday.
"We started operating at 60 percent runs in early October and we later increased it to 80 percent," the source told Reuters.

The 100,000 barrels per day refinery, also known as the Dalian West Pacific Petrochemical Co (WEPEC), is jointly owned by the China's Ministry of Chemical Industry (5 percent), Dalian municipality's (16.17 percent), Daqing Municipality (15 percent), state refiner SINOPEC (16.33 percent), state trader SINOCHEM (27.5 percent) and French oil company Total (20 percent).
Sources at the refinery and WEPEC said the refinery will not be exporting any products this year.
They said the refinery might begin exports next year but they could not provide further details.
The refinery was built as an export-oriented refinery. About 70 percent of output was to be geared to exports.
Sources said oil products from the refinery have so far been sold in the domestic market in Dalian, Liaoning province on the north west coast.
They said the refinery was still in the process of starting up and so was continuing to test runs.
"When it is fully operational and the oil products meet international market standards, we would start to export," the source at WEPEC said.
The source at the refinery said he is confident the refinery would be able to reach full capacity "soon".
